sanskrit:
नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः।
न चैनं क्लेदयन्त्यापो न शोषयति मारुतः॥
transliteration:
nainaṁ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṁ dahati pāvakaḥ |
na cainaṁ kledayanty āpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ ||
translation: Weapons cannot cut the soul, fire cannot burn it, water cannot wet it, nor can wind dry it.
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna continues his teaching on the indestructible nature of the Atman (soul). He employs vivid imagery from the physical world to illustrate that the soul transcends all material elements and their effects. The four primary elements—earth (represented by weapons), fire, water, and air—which can destroy or transform all physical matter, have absolutely no power over the eternal soul. This verse emphasizes the categorical difference between the material body and the spiritual essence.

The systematic negation of each element's power over the soul serves a pedagogical purpose. Krishna addresses the natural human tendency to identify with the physical body by demonstrating that the true self is completely beyond physical laws and limitations. Weapons represent solid matter and mechanical force; fire represents transformation and destruction through heat; water represents dissolution; and wind represents desiccation. None of these forces, which govern the entire material realm, can affect the soul in any way.

This teaching is crucial in the context of Arjuna's dilemma on the battlefield. By understanding that the soul is eternally indestructible and untouched by physical violence, Arjuna can transcend his grief over the apparent killing of his relatives. The verse establishes the philosophical foundation for karma yoga—performing one's duty without attachment to physical outcomes, knowing that the eternal essence of all beings remains forever unchanged and inviolable.
speaker: Krishna
